title: 113_hr111
content: The Act may be cited as the "Filipino Veterans of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act". During World War II, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt commissioned around 250,000 troops from the Philippines into active service for the United States. The United States War Department formed the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), which included the Filipino Infantry Regiment composed of first-generation immigrants and second-generation Filipino-American soldiers. The Philippine Scout units were directly recruited by the United States Army. During World War II, Filipino soldiers responded to President Roosevelt's call-to-arms and fought under the American flag. They shared the same fate as American troops at Bataan, Corregidor, and the "Death March," making many sacrifices. During World War II, Filipino soldiers fought alongside American troops in the Far East and as guerilla fighters during the Japanese occupation of the Philippines. The Rescission Act of 1946 later denied them recognition as active military members, but Congress acknowledges their courage and bravery. The United States is forever grateful for their dedication and sacrifice. The commitment and sacrifice of Filipino soldiers during World War II demonstrate exceptional patriotism and honor. The commitment and sacrifice of Filipino soldiers during World War II demonstrate exceptional patriotism and honor. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be awarded to Filipino Veterans of World War II. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. After the award, the gold medal will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display. The gold medal awarded to Filipino Veterans of World War II will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research. Congress suggests that the medal should also be displayed at other locations associated with the veterans. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze to cover costs. Medals struck under this Act are considered national medals and numismatic items. Authorization of appropriations and proceeds of sale are also addressed. Authorization of up to $30,000 from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund is allowed to cover the cost of the medal authorized under section 3. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited into the same fund. The term "Filipino Veterans of World War II" is defined as those who served honorably in various capacities under the United States Armed Forces or Philippine Army during the specified period.
